user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint64_to_str:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint64_to_str (uint64_t val,
                   char *buf,
                   size_t buf_size)
{
  char *chr;  /**< pointer to the current printed digit */
  /* The biggest printable number is 18446744073709551615 */
  uint64_t divisor = UINT64_C (10000000000000000000);
  int digit;

  chr = buf;
  digit = (int) (val / divisor);
  mhd_assert (digit < 10);

  /* Do not print leading zeros */
  while ((0 == digit) && (1 < divisor))
  {
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }

  while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val %= divisor;
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
  return 0; /* The buffer is too small */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val %= divisor;
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. All statements in the fragment are reachable: if buf_size is initially zero the while loop is skipped and the final 'return 0' is executed; inside the loop the 'if (1 == divisor) return ...' returns when the last digit has been written; otherwise the loop continues (buf_size was decremented each iteration) until either divisor==1 (return inside loop) or buf_size becomes zero (loop exits and the trailing 'return 0' is executed). There is no code rendered unreachable by constant conditions or unconditional jumps, so MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is not violated.
